content.body: bakkot: what is "1. If NewTarget is undefined or the active function object, throw a TypeError exception." intended to do in the Iterator constructor? throw on creating empty iterators?
content.formatted_body: bakkot: what is "1. If NewTarget is undefined or the active function object, throw a TypeError exception." intended to do in the Iterator constructor? throw on creating empty iterators?

content.body: uhh that spec text predates my involvement. I guess it is intended to make `Iterator` essentially an abstract class?
content.formatted_body: uhh that spec text predates my involvement. I guess it is intended to make Iterator essentially an abstract class?

content.body: i.e. you can't instantiate it directly, only inherit from it
okay
(that's the "active function object" bit; the "undefined" is what makes it not invokable without `new`)
content.formatted_body: (that's the "active function object" bit; the "undefined" is what makes it not invokable without new)

content.body: that's... fine i guess?
yes, i meant the active function object bit
tbh I didn't notice that was there
that's a behavior i've never implemented before
so wanted to double check
cc snek
like i guess it'd be pretty useless to call new Iterator(), so it's fine to error
I could imagine doing something like `let x = new Iterator(); x.next = () => ({ done: false, value: 0 })`, I guess
content.formatted_body: I could imagine doing something like let x = new Iterator(); x.next = () => ({ done: false, value: 0 }), I guess

content.body: but `let x = { __proto__: Iterator.prototype, next: () => ({ done: false, value: 0 }) }` works just as well if you want that
content.formatted_body: but let x = { __proto__: Iterator.prototype, next: () => ({ done: false, value: 0 }) } works just as well if you want that

content.body: some people are averse to the `__proto__` syntax but like whatever
content.formatted_body: some people are averse to the __proto__ syntax but like whatever

content.body: it does seem like a kind of unnecessary restriction
otoh it genuinely is abstract in that you need to provide your own `next`
content.formatted_body: otoh it genuinely is abstract in that you need to provide your own next

content.body:
> <@bakkot:matrix.org> uhh that spec text predates my involvement. I guess it is intended to make `Iterator` essentially an abstract class?

This is something for which I've wanted to add formal syntax for awhile (i.e., `abstract class`). Hopefully having the concept of an abstract class as built in might make it easier to get a proposal adopted

content.body: wait why is Iterator.prototype non-configurable?
we don't do that for other prototypes do we
My phone says we do?
yeah `.prototype`s are non-configurable by default
but writable on function declarations and maybe some other functions?
wait
hol up
you are correct
i was confused by the iterator-adjacent prototypes, like https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-generatorfunction.prototype.prototype
which are configurable
i guess the question is then why are those configurable
